author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> just brought up in an issue that they believe that links to EIPs within EIPs should be absolute paths to `eips.ethereum.org/EIPs/eip-#.md`.  I have been told in the past (long time ago) that they should be relative paths like `./eip-#.md`.

author: sky.cactus
content: I also believe pretty strongly that we **SHOULD** be using relative paths, as it means the page works in GitHub, forks of GitHub, the EIPs page, if the EIPs page moves, in mirrors of the EIPs page, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: Do others have an opinion on the matter and/or is there an official stance written out somewhere (e.g., EIP-1 or something)?

author: sky.cactus
content: Hehe, glancing at EIP-1, it internally uses `[EIP-#]` which on the EIPs site renders as a link to GitHub.  ðŸ˜¬

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP-1 does explicitly say to use relative paths for asset links: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-1.md#eip-formats-and-templates

author: sky.cactus
content: However, it doesn't mention whether to use relative paths for other EIPs or not.

author: axic3354
content: Images are handled differently by Jekyll than other links.

author: sky.cactus
content: Just trying to gather available info at the moment to facilitate discussion, didn't mean to imply that that was a strong argument.

author: axic3354
content: Here's the context (and I added more comments there): https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/2488#discussion_r479080345

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> Do you remember what the argument for absolute paths was?  Generally speaking, relative paths are preferred in most web contexts (and often in desktop contexts as well), so I'm surprised that a discussion would result in absolute paths for this sort of thing as it breaks a lot.

author: axic3354
content: Not entirely, but one driving force was to ensure people consider the rendered version on eips.ethereum.org as the "absolute truth". As you've uncovered above, with relative links sometimes the rendered version moves people off the rendered version back to github. This may be a shortcoming in Jekyll, or the settings we use for Jekyll.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, so I definitely agree that eips.ethereum.org shouldn't be directing people to GitHub, but having relative paths wouldn't cause that I don't think?

author: sky.cactus
content: Let me see, I have merged some PRs recently that had relative paths, so should be easy to verify.

author: axic3354
content: I've spent quite a bit of time improving the Jekyll configuration in the past 2 years so maybe it is not an issue anymore, but I haven't specifically spent time on this issue.

author: axic3354
content: Btw, I wish the repo is kept consistent and changes like this are done at once with consensus.

author: sky.cactus
content:
At the moment, Jekyll appears to do the right thing.
<https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2711>
<https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/blob/master/EIPS/eip-2711.md>
Look for EIP-2718 on that page and note that it links to ethereum.org in the first and github.com in the second.  Uses relative paths internally.

author: axic3354
content: This means I'd prefer we keep using absolute paths (including those recently merged ones), and do a once-off sweep to relative paths, if that is agreed on.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Btw, I wish the repo is kept consistent and changes like this are done at once with consensus.
<@!425279588009246720> I agree with the consistency angle, which is why I wanted to discuss.  I have been merging stuff with relative paths lately (and advising users on relative paths) because that is how I was trained years ago.

author: sky.cactus
content: My vote is strongly in favor of relative paths for the reasons mentioned above.  **IFF** we come to consensus on that I'll do a PR that updates everything to relative paths repository wide.  **IFF** we come to consensus on absolute paths, then I'll approve a PR that updates everything to absolute paths (and I'll start recommending such to authors going forward).

author: axic3354
content: Oh I think another reason for linking to actual EIPs with absolute path was that if someone is looking at a github fork for a given EIP, they may see an outdated version of the linked EIP.

author: sky.cactus
content: They will still see an outdated version of the EIP even if that EIP has an absolute link.

author: axic3354
content: Why? The absolute link goes to the official repository.

author: sky.cactus
content: I feel like the set of people who will end up on a random fork and then navigate to the latest via link and then continue browsing is a pretty small set.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, I don't know anyone who just "browses around EIPs" like Wikipedia.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe there exists some set of users who do this?  Are they users who are *also* likely to start off looking at some outdated fork?

author: axic3354
content: Some large EIPs had the tendency to link to their fork of the EIP repository for discussions. It is an edge case and not something we should be a proponent of, anyway.
